DataElement.preferredName: Molecular Analysis Histone Gene Family Variant Type
DataElement.preferredDefinition: The text term used to describe a specific histone variant, which are proteins that substitute for the core canonical histones.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Molecular Analysis Histone Gene Family Variant
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: A laboratory procedure that involves the study of tissues, cells, and fluids using DNA/RNA analysis techniques for the identification of characteristics and abnormalities at the molecular level._Major protein component of chromatin.  Highly conserved basic proteins, originally classified into classes based on the relative amounts of arginine and lysine in each protein.  The various classes are now termed H1, H2A, H2B, H3, and H4.  In chromatin, they are found in an octamer, containing two each of H2A, H2B, H3, and H4, complexed with DNA in nucleosomes.  The histones in the octamer complex are also known as the core histones.  The H1 class of histones, termed the linker histones, is loosely associated with the nucleosome._A set of genes coding for diverse proteins which, by virtue of their high degree of sequence similarity, are believed to have evolved from a single ancestral gene._An alteration or difference from a norm or standard.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: Techniques for studying or analyzing the genetic composition and mechanisms of living organisms at the molecular level. May refer to the understanding and manipulation of genes (DNA).

Concepts.definition: A laboratory procedure that involves the study of tissues, cells, and fluids using DNA/RNA analysis techniques for the identification of characteristics and abnormalities at the molecular level.

The histones in the octamer complex are also known as the core histones.  The H1 class of histones, termed the linker histones, is loosely associated with the nucleosome.:A set of genes coding for diverse proteins which, by virtue of their high degree of sequence similarity, are believed to have evolved from a single ancestral gene.:An alteration or difference from a norm or standard.

The various classes are now termed H1, H2A, H2B, H3, and H4.  In chromatin, they are found in an octamer, containing two each of H2A, H2B, H3, and H4, complexed with DNA in nucleosomes.  The histones in the octamer complex are also known as the core histones.  The H1 class of histones, termed the linker histones, is loosely associated with the nucleosome.

An alteration or difference from a norm or standard.

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: Major protein component of chromatin.  Highly conserved basic proteins, originally classified into classes based on the relative amounts of arginine and lysine in each protein.  The various classes are now termed H1, H2A, H2B, H3, and H4.  In chromatin, they are found in an octamer, containing two each of H2A, H2B, H3, and H4, complexed with DNA in nucleosomes.  The histones in the octamer complex are also known as the core histones.  The H1 class of histones, termed the linker histones, is loosely associated with the nucleosome._An alteration or difference from a norm or standard._Something distinguishable as an identifiable class based on common qualities.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: Any specific activity undertaken during the course of a clinical study or research protocol.
